agent_utterance: For the next 3 days, after each main meal, add one palm-sized portion of lean protein and one cup of non-starchy vegetables, then quickly log that you did it and rate your craving on a 0–10 scale. Keep it simple and non-judgmental—if you miss a meal, just reset at the next one and continue.

agent_utterance: Post-meal, add one palm-sized portion of lean protein and one cup of non-starchy vegetables. After you finish, quickly log that you did it and rate your craving on a 0–10 scale. If you miss a meal, reset at the next one and keep going. To support consistency, keep a couple of protein options (e.g., chicken, fish, tofu) and a couple of veggie options (e.g., steamed broccoli, leafy greens) on hand so it’s easy to implement without extra decision-making.
agent_monologue: To gently elevate the user toward a steadier, mid-range behavior without triggering guilt, I’m pairing a concrete, repeatable post-meal action with easy-to-use logging. agent_utterance: After your next main meal, add a palm-sized portion of lean protein and a cup of non-starchy vegetables, then log it and rate your craving on a 0–10 scale. To support consistency without pressure, take a 60-second mood check after logging: name what you’re feeling and pick one tiny non-food coping step if cravings rise (drink water, take a short walk, or a quick protein snack). If you slip, reset at the next meal and keep focusing on steady progress.
agent_monologue: CBT-style reasoning: The user benefits from structured, minimal actions that reinforce a sense of control. A post-meal micro-action plus immediate logging provides cue-reinforcement and reduces decision fatigue, while a brief emotional check helps distinguish hunger from BED triggers, nudging toward a steadier behavior trajectory toward the goal.
